profiles.desc:
Use Access Profiles to setup your Profiled Internet Access policies.
Implement your policies, by creating a logical order of Entries.
Each Request within a connection, and the Response received from the remote web server:
  • is first evaluated against the Default Policies List of Entries,
  • and then aganst the Secondary Policies List of Entries.
After all Entries are tested:
  1. The Connection will be Blocked if the resultant Action is not set to Allow.
  2. The Resultant Connection's Profiles then determines the applicability of the Policy Entries in the other Configurable Sections.

defaults.desc:
Connections are tested against the Secondary Policies List after they are tested against the Default Policies List.
The Policies List of Entries is processed top-down for each request and response in a Connection.
Implement your Policies, by creating a logical order of Entries.
Each Entry consists of Rules for testing applicability.
An Entry is applicable only if a Request matches all the Rules of an Entry.
When an Entry is applicable:
  1. The corresponding set of Added Profiles, is appended to the Connection's Profiles
  2. The corresponding set of Removed Profiles, is deleted from the Connection's Profiles
  3. The corresponding Action is set against the Connection.
  4. The Request is now tested against subsequent Entry, based on the resulting state of modified Connection's Profiles

profile.desc:
Connections are tested against the Secondary Policies List after they are tested against the Default Policies List.
The Policies List of Entries is processed top-down for each request and response in a Connection.
Implement your Policies, by creating a logical order of Entries.
Each Entry consists of Rules for testing applicability.
An Entry is applicable only if a Request matches all the Rules of an Entry.
When an Entry is applicable:
  1. The corresponding set of Added Profiles, is appended to the Connection's Profiles
  2. The corresponding set of Removed Profiles, is deleted from the Connection's Profiles
  3. The corresponding Action is set against the Connection.
  4. The Request is now tested against subsequent Entry, based on the resulting state of modified Connection's Profiles

comment.desc:
For documentation, and future references, explain the relevance of this entry with your policies.

That is, by reading the policies, a future user can understand the purpose of that entry.

profile_tracing.desc:
Enable or Disable Tracing of this entry

Select "Yes" to debug the application of entry using SafeSquid logs.

"Enable entry tracing" is useful if you wish to validate its application.

proxyhost.desc:
Leave this blank, if this configuration is not shared across multiple instances of SafeSquid.

Leave it blank to apply this entry to all your instances of SafeSquid.

Specify the hostname(s) of the instances, for which this entry should be applicable, if multiple instances share this configuration.

Mostly used in master-slave and cluster environments.

profiles.desc:
Specify the list of Profiles for which this entry should be applicable.

Leave it Blank, to ignore this applicability test.

Leave it Blank, to apply for all connections irrespective of their Profile.

To avoid application of this entry to a connection that has a profile, use negation (!profile).

time_profiles.desc:
Specify the list of Time Profile(s) for which this entry should be applicable.

Leave it Blank, to ignore this applicability test.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has at-least one of the specified Time Profile(s).

To avoid application of this entry to a connection that has a Time Profile, use negation (!Weekday).

Go to Time Profiler to review, or define new Time Profiles.

user_groups.desc:
Specify the list of User Group(s), to which this entry is applicable.

Leave it Blank, to ignore this applicability test.

If one or more User Groups is/are specified, this entry will be applicable after it is determined, if user authentication is required. If user authentication is required, then this entry will be applicable only after successful user authentication.

This entry will be applicable only if the connection has at-least one of the specified User Group(s).

To avoid application to a connection for specific User Group(s), use negation (!User Group).

Go to Access Restrictions to review or define new User Groups.

req_types.desc:
List of Request Types or application categories, to which this entry will be applicable.

The connection should have been already profiled to have one or more of these Request Types or application categories.

Use Negation "!", to check this entry only, when specified Request Types or application categories are not applied to the connection.

Leave it Blank to check this entry irrespective of applied Request Types or application categories.

If you set this to "Browsers,Skype,Webinar,!Safari", then this entry will be applicable to only those connections that have been profiled as Browsers, or Skype or Webinar, or not profiled as Safari.

web_categories.desc:
List of categories, to which this entry will be applicable.

The connection should have been already categorized to have one or more of these categories.

Use Negation "!", to check this entry only, when specified categories are not applied to the connection.

Leave it Blank to check this entry irrespective of applied categories.

If you set this to "Social,Chat,IM,!Porn ", then this entry will be applicable to only those connections that have been categorized as Social, or Chat, or IM, or not categorized as Porn.

res_types.desc:
List of Response Types or content categories, to which this entry will be applicable.

The connection should have been already profiled to have one or more of these Response Types or content categories.

Use Negation "!", to check this entry only, when specified Response Types or content categories are not applied to the connection.

Leave it Blank to check this entry irrespective of applied Response Types or content categories.

If you set this to "Image,Pdf,Audio,!Text,!Jpeg", then this entry will be applicable to only those connections that have been profiled as Image, or Pdf, or Audio, or not profiled as Text or Jpeg.

action.desc:
Specify action to enforce on matched connections.

ALLOW: Allow users to access.Default action. When action is allow SafeSquid uses applied profiles to do various filtering. Otherwise blocks access without doing further filtering.

DENY: Block access but allow users to bypass and access sites for couple of hours. You can configure bypass access to the users using access restrictions.

DO NOT BYPASS: Strictly Block access.

INHERIT: Apply previously applied action.

add_profiles.desc:
Specify the list of Profiles, to append to the connection’s existing Profiles, if the all applicability test rules match.

Subsequent applicable Entry may further modify the connection’s Profiles.

Define a new Profile(s), or Select previously defined Profile(s) from the drop-down menu to apply to the connection, if they match this entry.

When defining a new Profile, use terms that uniquely represent your needs.

You can use added profiles in Virus scanning, SSL inspection and other filtering sections.

remove_profiles.desc:
Select profiles to remove from connection when matches.

The connection should have been already profiled to have one or more of these profiles.

Use remove profiles adequately to ensure white-list profiles does not conflict with block profiles.

When a connection matches to block profile and as well white-list profile then your white-list entry should be configured with to remove block profile from connection.

Leave it Blank to ignore.

FALSE.desc: Select this to disable profile tracing.

TRUE.desc: Select this to enable profile tracing.

ALLOW.desc: Select this, if you want to allow requests or responses matching this policy

DENY.desc: Select, if you want to block requests or responses matching this policy. Will not block the requests or responses to those users who have allow bypass set from the access section.

INHERIT.desc: Select, if you want to apply the action based on previous profiles match up.

DO_NOT_BYPASS.desc: Select, if you want to strictly block the websites.

zero.desc: Enforce network traffic to be routed through an alternate outbound IP.

Bypass inspection of SSL/TLS encrypted traffic.
Tunnel Non-Browser applications to remote web servers.
Facilitate use of Client side SSL certificates for Digital Signature.

one.desc: Allow traffic to websites with self-signed certificates.

two.comment: BYPASS NO ISSUER CERT LOCALLY ERROR
two.value: BYPASS NO ISSUER CERT LOCALLY ERROR
two.desc: Bypass SSL errors for incomplete certificate chain due to missing issuer certificates.

zero.desc: Bypass scanning of request and response payloads with ClamAV.

one.desc: Enforce scanning of request and response payloads with ClamAV.

zero.desc: Bypass scanning of request and response payloads with Text Analyzer.

one.desc: Enforce scanning of request and response payloads with Text Analyzer.

zero.desc:
Enforces Bing search queries to use Bing SafeSearch feature, which filters out explicit content from search results.
This ensures a safer browsing environment by limiting exposure to potentially harmful or inappropriate content.

one.desc:
Enforces Google search queries through Google SafeSearch setting, effectively filtering explicit content from search outcomes.
This ensures a safer browsing environment by limiting exposure to potentially harmful or inappropriate content.

two.desc:
Enforces YouTube's SafeSearch filtering to all YouTube video searches, minimizing explicit or inappropriate video content.
This ensures a safer browsing environment by limiting exposure to potentially harmful or inappropriate content.

three.desc:
Enforces Yahoo search settings to utilize Yahoo SafeSearch feature, which screens out explicit content from search findings.
This ensures a safer browsing environment by limiting exposure to potentially harmful or inappropriate content.

four.desc:
Enforces DuckDuckGo search engine uses its Safe Search mode to exclude explicit content from search results.
This ensures a safer browsing environment by limiting exposure to potentially harmful or inappropriate content.

zero.desc:
Bypass image filtering for disabling content-based blocking. Intended to prevent false positives in content blocking, ensuring legitimate access is not incorrectly denied.
Use this bypass cautiously, as it could potentially allow sensitive or inappropriate content to pass through unchecked.

one.desc:
Enforce image filtering to block images from websites which servers pornographic content, including surrogate websites.
Image filter blocks inappropriate images by analyzing the graphical content of an image, in real time.
Prevents such material from being accessed or displayed.

two.desc:
Enforce highest level of scrutiny for image scanning, designed to detect and block pornographic content with extreme precision.
Image filter blocks inappropriate images by analyzing the graphical content of an image, in real time.
Effective against surrogate websites known to serve such content.

zero.desc:
Allows all types of file uploads without restrictions.
Use this setting for environments where data sharing is unrestricted and the risk of sensitive data loss is considered low, or DLP is been taken care somewhere else in your network.

one.desc:
Blocks all file uploads to prevent potential data leaks.
Ideal for highly sensitive environments where the prevention of any unauthorized data transfer is critical.

two.desc: Permits the upload of Excel documents (.xls, .xlsx), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

three.desc: Permits the upload of Word documents (.doc, .docx), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

four.desc: Permits the upload of PowerPoint presentations (.ppt, .pptx), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

five.desc: Permits the upload of PDF files (.pdf), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

six.desc: Permits the upload of compressed files (.zip), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

seven.desc: Permits the upload of image files (e.g., .jpg, .png, .gif), ensuring that data sharing is limited to specific types of documents.

zero.desc: Drop all cookies sent in Request and Response Headers, and thus prevent login.

Prevent use of personal account and force use of corporate email account for Google mail.
Header Filtering policy inserts X-GoogApps in request headers sent for Google user authentication.

one.desc:
Enforces YouTube's "Strict" restriction mode across our network, aiming to filter out potentially adult content and ensure a safer browsing environment.
Header Filtering policy inserts YouTube-Restrict: Strict in request headers sent for youtube videos.

two.desc:
Enforces CSP headers to enhance web application security by preventing XSS attacks, data injection, and other malicious content from executing.
Header Filtering policy inserts YouTube-Content-Security-Policy in response headers received for all requests.

zero.desc: Bypass enforcement of Elevated Privacy. Permit Third-Party transactions.

one.desc:
Prevent third-party cookies
Third-party cookies are often used by advertisers and tracking services to monitor user activity across multiple websites, potentially compromising user privacy.

two.desc: Prevent cookie exchange, hide referrer, and user-agent Third-party cookies are used for tracking users across multiple websites, while the HTTP(s) referrer and user-agent data can be exploited to identify and profile individuals.

zero.desc:
Enforces regulated download speeds for optimized network performance, prioritizing equitable access and preventing bandwidth hogging.
Useful in networks with slow internet speeds, ensuring that available bandwidth is fairly distributed among users for smoother online experiences.

one.desc: Enforces regulated on maximum number of bytes that can be downloaded for optimized network performance, prioritizing equitable access and preventing bandwidth hogging, useful in networks with slow internet speeds, ensuring that available bandwidth is fairly distributed among users for smoother online experiences.

two.desc: Enforces regulated upload speeds for optimized network performance, prioritizing equitable access and preventing bandwidth hogging, useful in networks with slow internet speeds, ensuring that available bandwidth is fairly distributed among users for smoother online experiences.
